title: Opinion | Even Before the Tears Stopped, She Took Action
text:
The hours and days and weeks after her 14-year-old daughter, Alyssa, was killed in the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., are a blur. But some things Lori Alhadeff remembers. She remembers how she and her husband and sons tucked family pictures and a favorite pink teddy bear into the coffin before closing it, and how she kept her own fingers pressed against that coffin, even as it was being lowered into the ground. She does not remember screaming when it slipped, finally, from her reach. Friends later described the sound she made as unlike anything they had ever heard.

By then, Mrs. Alhadeff thinks, her daughter’s spirit had already taken up residence inside of her.

How else to explain the distinct change she felt? Or her rapid conversion from reserved, bashful soccer mom into outspoken school safety advocate? Just hours after completing funeral arrangements, she had walked up to one of the cable news teams dotting the local park and asked for the camera to be turned on. “I have something to say,” she explained, before unleashing a raw, angry screed that would quickly go viral.

“Our kids need safety now,” she screamed. “Do something!”

Mrs. Alhadeff had never been one to yell. It was Alyssa whose voice always carried; Alyssa who was known as “the smallest girl” on her soccer team with “the loudest voice.” It was also Alyssa who loved to join and participate and compete, and Alyssa whose persistence and sharp negotiating skills made a lifetime of victories seem so assured.
description: As have other parents whose children were shot down at school, Lori Alhadeff is fighting for change.
